description: Batumi Piazza is a charming 5,700-square-meter Italian-style public square nestled in the heart of Old Batumi, Georgia. Completed in 2010, this architectural gem was designed by Georgian architect Vazha Orbeladze, who drew inspiration from Italy's iconic Piazza della Signoria in Florence, despite the square being named after Venice's Piazza San Marco. The plaza represents a modern interpretation of Venetian architecture seamlessly integrated into one of Batumi's most historic districts, creating the illusion of a small Italian town on Georgia's Black Sea coast. The centerpiece of the square is Europe's largest figurative marble mosaic, measuring 106 square meters and comprised of 88,244,735 individual pieces, each one square centimeter, combined into 1,764,895 segments. Created by Georgian-Swiss designer Natalia de Pita Amirejibi in 2010, the mosaic features five female sea deities in a composition of eight concentric circles representing the eternal motion of the sea and continuous urban development. The square is surrounded by buildings constructed in 2009 featuring stunning stained-glass windows by renowned Estonian artist Dolores Hoffmann, intricate facades, and a magnificent clock tower that now houses a boutique hotel. Since opening, Batumi Piazza has become the city's premier venue for cultural and entertainment events, hosting world-famous musicians including Placido Domingo, Sting, Chris Botti, Macy Gray, and Michel Legrand.
highlights: Europe's largest figurative marble mosaic at 106 square meters contains 88,244,735 individual pieces of marble collected from fifteen countries worldwide, each measuring exactly one square centimeter and assembled into 1,764,895 segments under the personal supervision of designer Natalia de Pita Amirejibi.

The central mosaic features five female sea deity figures dressed in distinct colors (red, blue, purple, pink, and green) arranged in eight concentric circles, with the prototype of the central little mermaid character being the designer's five-year-old daughter, Romina.

Stunning stained-glass windows throughout the square were created by renowned Estonian artist Dolores Hoffmann, who was personally commissioned by then-President Mikheil Saakashvili in 2010 after he visited her Tallinn studio.

The ornate clock tower serves as the architectural focal point, blending traditional Georgian and classical European architecture with decorative Eastern-style motifs, and now operates as a tasteful boutique hotel.
The square occupies an entire city block that once housed a school, making it a hidden gem tucked behind surrounding buildings that visitors can easily walk past without realizing its presence.
World-class concert venue that has hosted legendary performers including opera tenor Placido Domingo, jazz trumpeter Chris Botti, rock icon Sting, soul singer Macy Gray, and composer Michel Legrand.

The buildings surrounding the piazza were all constructed in 2009 based on architect Vazha Orbeladze's designs, who intended them to slot seamlessly into Batumi's historic district while creating an authentic Italian atmosphere.

During summer months, the square transforms into an open-air music stage featuring regular concerts of Georgian and Adjarian folk ensembles, with weekend live rock performances at The Quiet Woman, Batumi's first authentic Irish pub.
tips: Visit late afternoon for coffee at outdoor cafes or after sunset for live music and wine, when the decorative lighting transforms the square into an even cozier, more atmospheric space.

To fully appreciate the intricate marble mosaic, seek out the 'secret balcony' on upper floors of surrounding buildings, as the artwork is difficult to view properly while standing on the square itself.
Read the informational sign near the mosaic in full to discover an amusing 'easter egg' revealing laziness on the part of those who installed it.
Arrive between May and September for the best experience, when warm weather brings open-air concerts, vibrant street performances, and local festivals to the square.
Bring cash for local vendors and smaller cafes that may not accept cards, and budget 10-30 GEL (3-10 USD) for coffee or meals, noting that Piazza prices are higher than elsewhere in Batumi.
Visit on Sunday mornings to browse markets where local artists and artisans sell handcrafted works, or come daily during peak season when stalls featuring artisanal products operate.

If booking a hotel around the square, request a room away from the courtyard to avoid absurdly loud lounge music until midnight and frequent loud gongs from the clock tower that disturb light sleepers.
Explore early morning for peaceful people-watching and beautiful lighting for photography, before the crowds arrive and cafes open around 8 AM.
Check local event listings before visiting to catch scheduled concerts or cultural performances, as the square serves as Batumi's largest venue for entertainment events.
Wear comfortable walking shoes as the square and surrounding Old Batumi district are best explored on foot over cobblestone and mosaic surfaces.
Look for boy statues with flutes near the Piazza as you explore the surrounding streets of the historic district.
Stop by The Quiet Woman Irish pub on weekends for live rock concerts alongside original draft beers including Guinness, Harp, Hoegaarden, Krombacher, and London Pride.
vibe: Batumi Piazza exudes a transported-to-Italy atmosphere that feels simultaneously authentic and delightfully surreal in its Georgian context. The square pulses with a distinctly European cafe culture vibe, where locals and tourists alike settle into outdoor terraces for leisurely coffee sessions and extended people-watching. By day, the mood is relaxed and contemplative, with sunlight filtering through Dolores Hoffmann's colorful stained-glass windows and casting rainbow patterns across the intricate marble mosaic at your feet. The architectural intimacy of the enclosed square creates a cozy, almost theatrical setting, as if you've stumbled onto a carefully designed stage set for Italian life. As afternoon transitions to evening, the energy shifts dramatically. Decorative lighting illuminates the ornate facades, the clock tower glows against the darkening sky, and the space transforms into Batumi's liveliest cultural hub. Live music spills from multiple venues, creating an eclectic soundtrack that ranges from traditional Georgian folk melodies to contemporary rock performances. The atmosphere becomes festive and convivial, with the clink of wine glasses, animated conversations in multiple languages, and the aromatic blend of Georgian and European cuisines wafting from surrounding restaurants. Despite being artificial and newly constructed (2009-2010), the square has successfully cultivated an aged, timeless quality that makes it feel like a historic gathering place. There's a palpable sense of local pride mixed with tourist curiosity, as Batumians treat this as a beloved community space rather than merely a attraction.
expectations: The square will be an easy-to-find landmark prominently featured on the waterfront or main streets of Batumi.
As an Italian-inspired plaza, it will closely resemble Venice's Piazza San Marco, with open colonnades, pigeons, and grand waterfront views.
The mosaic and stained glass will be prominently displayed and easily viewed from standing level on the square.
Prices at the restaurants and cafes will be similar to other establishments throughout Batumi.
The square will be a peaceful, quiet retreat for relaxation away from Batumi's bustling tourist areas.
reality: The square is cleverly hidden behind surrounding buildings in Old Batumi, occupying an entire city block where a school once stood, and you can easily walk right past it without realizing you're close.

While named after Piazza San Marco, architect Vazha Orbeladze actually drew inspiration from Florence's Piazza della Signoria, creating a more enclosed, intimate square without water views but with a distinctive clock tower and compact Italian town atmosphere.

The 106-square-meter marble mosaic is best appreciated from a 'secret balcony' on upper floors of surrounding buildings rather than ground level, where the intricate details of 88 million pieces are difficult to fully comprehend.

Restaurants and cafes charge noticeably higher prices than elsewhere in Batumi, with beer costing more than the typical 3 GEL found around the city, and some visitors report diluted drinks and disappointing food quality.

The square is actually Batumi's liveliest entertainment hub with near-constant live music, weekend rock concerts, and absurdly loud lounge music from hotel courtyards until midnight, plus frequent clock tower gongs that prevent sleep for light sleepers in nearby hotels.
unique_facts: The mosaic was created in 2010 at the Fantini Mosaici workshop in Abu Dhabi before being transported to Batumi and assembled on-site under designer Natalia de Pita Amirejibi's personal supervision.
Marble for the mosaic was sourced from fifteen different countries around the world, creating a truly international artwork in the heart of Georgia.
Designer Natalia de Pita Amirejibi used her five-year-old daughter Romina as the model for the central little mermaid figure in the mosaic.
Estonian stained-glass master Dolores Hoffmann received her commission directly from Georgian President Mikheil Saakashvili after he visited her studio in Tallinn in 2010.
The square's buildings were intentionally designed to create the illusion of age and historic continuity, despite all being constructed in 2009, just one year before the plaza opened.
Opera legend Placido Domingo performed at this relatively small public square, bringing world-class cultural prestige to what was essentially a new development.
The Quiet Woman became Batumi's first authentic Irish pub when it opened on Piazza Square in July 2011, complete with Georgian and European cuisine alongside traditional Irish draft beers.
The square operates 24/7 as a public space, though the true action happens when cafes open from 8 AM until midnight.

Despite being artificial and newly constructed, the plaza has become such a beloved local gathering spot that Batumi residents consider it a traditional community space rather than a tourist attraction.
The clock tower boutique hotel allows guests to literally sleep inside the square's most iconic architectural feature, surrounded by the nightly entertainment below.
Architect Vazha Orbeladze openly cited Piazza della Signoria in Florence as his primary inspiration, even though the square was officially named after Venice's Piazza San Marco.
Sunday artisan markets have become a tradition at the square, where local artists sell handcrafted works, extending the Italian piazza concept of a community marketplace.
surprises: You can walk directly past the square without noticing it exists, as it's completely hidden behind buildings rather than being an obvious open plaza on a main thoroughfare.
The informational sign near the mosaic contains a deliberate 'easter egg' that reveals amusing laziness by the installation crew, rewarding visitors who take time to read it thoroughly.
A 'secret balcony' exists specifically for viewing the mosaic properly, suggesting the designers anticipated the ground-level viewing challenge but provided an insider solution.
The square successfully hosts world-famous international performers like Sting and Placido Domingo in what amounts to an intimate, enclosed courtyard setting rather than a grand concert venue.
Local Batumi residents use the square as frequently as tourists, creating an authentic community atmosphere rather than the typical tourist-trap vibe of manufactured attractions.
The mosaic's concept merges 'eternal sea motion' with 'continuous urban development,' creating unexpected philosophical depth for what could have been merely decorative pavement.
Hotels surrounding the square come with a significant noise trade-off, as the romantic Italian atmosphere includes loud music until midnight and regular clock tower gongs throughout the night.
The entire complex, despite looking like a centuries-old Italian quarter, was built in 2009-2010, making it younger than many smartphones yet convincingly historic in appearance.
The five sea deity figures in the mosaic each wear different colored dresses (red, blue, purple, pink, green) to emphasize their distinct personalities, adding narrative depth to the artwork.
Beer prices at Piazza establishments are noticeably inflated compared to the rest of Batumi, with some visitors reporting diluted drinks, creating an unexpected budget consideration.
The square was built on the site of a former school, transforming an entire city block from an educational institution into a cultural entertainment district.
During peak season, artisan stalls operate daily rather than just on Sundays, turning the entire square into a continuous marketplace reminiscent of authentic Italian piazzas.
